entry.title: A Wish for CLI-Based ABAP
entry.content:
A Wish for CLI-Based ABAP

Lately I’ve been thinking a lot about where SAP development is heading — and where it feels like it isn’t.

Outside the SAP ecosystem, development has moved decisively toward text-based, terminal-driven workflows. Code lives in Git, workflows start in the CLI, automation is the default, and AI tools increasingly operate directly on source files.

Inside the SAP world, especially around extensibility, we often see the opposite: GUI-driven tools, browser-based editors, and logic that gets generated somewhere behind the scenes.

After working hands-on with extensibility in S/4HANA recently, that contrast became impossible to ignore. It led to a simple but persistent thought:

What if ABAP fully embraced a CLI-based, developer-centric development model?

Modern development has moved to the terminal

For many developers today, the terminal isn’t a niche preference — it’s the center of gravity.

Modern development typically means:

  • source code as plain text

  • Git as the system of record

  • the terminal as the control plane

  • automation and pipelines by default

  • AI tools working directly on repositories

Tools like Claude Code make this very tangible. You can sit in a terminal, point the AI at a repository, ask it to explain a codebase, refactor a module, or generate a patch — all as diffs against real files. No wizards, no GUIs — just text in, text out.

Once you get used to working this way, it’s hard not to expect the same experience everywhere.

ABAP lives in a different world

ABAP, by contrast, still revolves around the SAP system itself.

  • Code primarily lives in the database

  • The system is the source of truth

  • Changes move via transports

  • Git integration is optional, secondary, and often awkward

  • Development assumes a running backend, not a repository

Even tools like abapGit, as valuable as they are, don’t change this fundamental model. They bridge worlds — they don’t redefine which world ABAP belongs to.

This means ABAP is not Git-centric. It’s not repository-centric. And as a result, it doesn’t naturally fit into modern CLI-based or AI-assisted workflows.

Low-code doesn’t fix this — it exposes it

SAP’s clean-core strategy has pushed heavily toward Key User Extensibility:

  • Custom Fields

  • Custom Logic

  • Adapt UI

  • GUI-driven configuration with generated artifacts

From a governance and upgrade perspective, this makes sense.

From a developer perspective, it often highlights the core problem.

Custom Logic is still ABAP — typed, structured, technical — but:

  • written in browser editors

  • without proper refactoring or navigation

  • without native Git ownership

  • without automation-friendly workflows

It ends up in an awkward middle ground:

  • too restrictive for developers

  • too complex for actual key users

Low-code doesn’t remove the need for strong developer workflows. It makes the absence of them more visible.

Clean core needs better developer ergonomics, not less code

Clean core is the right goal. There’s no debate there.

But clean core should not mean:

  • hiding code from developers

  • forcing logic into GUIs

  • discouraging automation

  • accepting weaker tooling

In practice, clean core works best with:

  • explicit, text-based code

  • strong testability

  • traceability through Git

  • automation and CI/CD

All of that aligns far better with CLI-friendly, developer-centric workflows than with click-driven configuration.

“CLI-based ABAP” is shorthand for a deeper change

When developers ask for CLI-based ABAP, they’re not chasing trends. And looking at how CAP is designed, SAP also knows this.

They’re really asking for:

  • ABAP source as first-class text

  • Git as a native concept, not a side channel

  • syntax checks, ATC, and tests callable from automation

  • workflows that don’t require a GUI or heavy IDE

  • AI tools that can reason about ABAP like any other language

This doesn’t mean pretending SAP systems aren’t special.
It means acknowledging that system-centric development no longer scales.

Why VS Code actually matters

This is why SAP’s move toward VS Code support for ABAP is so interesting.

VS Code isn’t just another editor. It sits at the center of:

  • Git-first workflows

  • terminals

  • automation

  • AI-assisted development

If ABAP can genuinely move closer to that ecosystem — even gradually — a lot suddenly becomes possible:

  • real CI/CD

  • better collaboration

  • meaningful automation

  • AI tools that work with ABAP, not around it

VS Code isn’t the goal.
It’s a signal.

entry.title: Re: How to make standard Fiori apps open an extended Fior...
entry.content:
Hi @EdsonBravo93

I can see that you want to use same Semantic Object - Action with standard, you need to add a parameter named sap-priority and set the value to 1.

With this parameter you added to target mapping; if you give the users catalog including this target mapping by a role, even the user tries to open the standard application, your target mapping will override it. sap-priority = 1 means if user has this target mapping and the standard one, bring the priority target mapping.

Best Regards.

entry.title: Where are stored the SAPUI5 Debug Sources in the ABAP stack?
entry.content:
In my system S/4HANA 2023 FPS 01 ON-PREMISE, when I debug the Javascript part of a standard SAPUI5 application directly in the Web browser (Dev Tools), I don't want to work with the default minimized "xxxxxx.js" Javascript file (no line feeds, minimized variable names, no comment), I'm using the debug source file "xxxxxx-dbg.js" (via Ctrl+Shift+Alt+P > Select specific modules / Youtube video: Debug UI5 Application Smartly | UI5 Diagnostics Tool (2021)).

I know that the minimized files are stored in the "SAPUI5 ABAP repository" (SAP GUI transaction SE80 > BSP application), under the BSP application whose name is the SAPUI5 application name of the Fiori application. It's a fake BSP application, it's just used to store the SAPUI5 files. For instance, the Fiori app F0859 corresponds to the SAPUI5 application MM_SUPPIV_MANS1 (as shown in the SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library > Implementation information > Configuration > SAPUI5 Application), SE80 shows the minimized files, e.g. utils/QuantityFormatter.js:

For my information, where are stored the debug source files, e.g. where is utils/QuantityFormatter-dbg.js? (the original source files, containing line feeds, original function and variable names, comments)

Thank you.

Sandra

entry.title: Re: Where are stored the SAPUI5 Debug Sources in the ABAP stack?
entry.content:
The debug sources are stored at the root of the BSP application with a technical name starting with "UI5". The correspondance between the real name and the technical name is stored in the file UI5RepositoryPathMapping.xml at the root of the BSP application. Here is the correspondance for utils/QuantityFormatter-dbg.js:

Code of UI5E134F618C9A8E7E08C76004F3EF0E4367209D406 (alias utils/QuantityFormatter-dbg.js):

For information, the code in the red box above corresponds to the below part of the minified source code ("D" corresponds to iDecimal, "f" corresponds to _oQuantityModel, etc.):

Note that the SAPUI5 Javascript SAP notes always deliver both the minified and debug sources e.g. 3680459 - F0859: Fiori app freezes after posting parked Supplier Invoice - SAP for Me. Here, UI55E0142F8D06AD51E1D4479D03C87000C32CFEBD2 is the debug source of the minified source SHAREUTIL.JS:

The content of this note also shows that the UI5* files don't always contain the debug source of a minified version, here component-preload.js is a minified version, and that the source files are not always minified (the TS TypeScript file). NB: I marked the two source files Component-h2-preload.js as minified, although they are technically not, because the debug source is almost as unreadable as the minified version...

For information, the explanation about UI5RepositoryPathMapping.xml was also given here: Solved: when using vs code to deploy Fiori to on premise, ... - SAP Community.

entry.title: Transfer of medical instruments and implants in Medical device Industry using S/4 HANA
entry.content:
Introduction:  

This blog outlines the leading medical device industry business process steps to Transfer medical instruments and implants needed in a surgery from one branch to another branch and provide visibility, tracking, and logistic support to the business process using S4 HANA

In the field instruments and implants can be physically transferred from branch to another branch based on demand and utilization, this process needs to accurately be captured in the SAP system.

When a request is received for transfer of instrument and implants between branches (consignees), from Branch A to Branch B, The SAP data model requires the execution of two transactions; first, a Consignment Pickup Order that pulls the product back to warehouse stock in the “plant of origin” and purpose-built “transfer storage location” not visible to ATP from Branch A and immediately transfer to Branch B with transfer-specific Consignment Fill Order that moves the product to the new branch.

Pre-requisite:

  • The goods requested for transfer are consigned in the system against branch A
  • Virtual storage location set up in S4 to move stock between the rep and not visible to ATP
  • Hospitals and branches must be set up as customers
  • Instruments and Consumables set up separate materials.

Setup Steps:

Configure new consignment document type: -

Step 1: Define Consignment fill up and pick up document types

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Sales document header – Define sales document type.

Consignment Pick up – To pick up inventory from branch A back to the warehouse and virtual storage location

Consignment Fill up. – To deliver inventory to sales rep B

Step 2: Define item categories.

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Sales document item – Define item categories

Consignment pick-up item category

Consignment Fill-up Item category.

Step 3: Schedule lines

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Schedule lines – Define schedule lines.

Consignment Pickup Schedule line.


Consignment Fill up the schedule line

Step 4: Assign document type to the sales area.

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Sales document header – Assign Sales Area to Sales Document Types

Step 5: Assign Item Categories

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Sales document item - Assign Item Categories

Step 6: Assign Schedule Line Categories

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Schedule lines - Assign Schedule Line Categories

Process steps: -

Step 1: - Create pick up order (KA) To pick up inventory from branch A

 


Step 2: Create Inbound delivery and receive goods in the warehouse of origin and virtual storage location.


Step 3. Create a Consignment fill up (KB) order transfer/deliver goods to branch B


Step 4: Create an outbound delivery with reference to the KB Order. Pick, pack, and Issue from the virtual storage location to rep B

Step 5: Asset updated with the new functional location

Conclusion:

  • After going through the above blog, the user should have learned how to transfer goods from one branch to another using S4 HANA
  • Please provide your feedback/comments. You can ask Question / Answer for the open Questions in the SAP Community here

Reference:

 SAP Help Portal

Authors: Mohan Kaliyamoorthy and Immanuel Godwin Johnson

entry.title: Fulfillment of Trial request to the field in Medical Device Industry using S/4 HANA
entry.content:
Introduction:  

This blog outlines the leading industry business process steps to fulfill and track customer request for trials in the field providing visibility to all stakeholders.

It is common practice in the medical industry for customers to request trial of new or modified products to determine effectiveness before placing orders.

The trial products sent out from the warehouse to field must be tracked and stored appropriately when returned as these can be used across customers and geographies. This document details the fulfillment of trial products


Pre-requisite:

  • Hospitals must be set up as customers and sales representatives as employees
  • Instruments and Consumables set up separate materials
  • Dedicated storage locations inside warehouses to store trial products
  1. Process Steps for Trial

 

Setup Steps:

Configure new consignment document type: -

Step 1: Define Consignment fill up and pick up document types

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Sales document header – Define sales document type.

Consignment Fill up. – To deliver trial inventory to customer


Consignment Pick up – To pick up inventory back to warehouse and dedicated storage location after trial


Step 2: Define item categories.

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Sales document item – Define item categories

Consignment Fill-up Item category.

 

Consignment pick-up item category

Step 3: Schedule lines

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Schedule lines – Define schedule lines.

Consignment Fill up the schedule line

 


Consignment Pickup Schedule line.


Step 4: Assign document type to the sales area.

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Sales document header – Assign Sales Area to Sales Document Types

Step 5: Assign Item Categories

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Sales document item - Assign Item Categories

Step 6: Assign Schedule Line Categories

SPRO – Sales and Distribution – Sales document- Schedule lines - Assign Schedule Line Categories

Process steps: -
Step 1. Create a Consignment fill up (KB) order send goods on trial from dedicated trial storage location


Step 2: Create an outbound delivery with reference to the KB Order. Pick, pack, and Issue from the virtual storage location to rep B

Step 4: Asset updated with the new functional location. Equipment identified as trial

Step 5: - Create pick up order (KA) To pick up inventory from customer location after trial


Step 2: Create Inbound delivery and receive goods in the warehouse of origin and virtual storage location.

 


Conclusion:

  • After going through the above blog, the user should have learned how to fulfill a customer request for trial of products using S4 HANA
  • Please provide your feedback/comments. You can ask Question / Answer for the open Questions in the SAP Community here

Reference:

 SAP Help Portal

Authors: Mohan Kaliyamoorthy and Immanuel Godwin Johnson

entry.title: Re: Header Condition in RFQ & Quotation - SAP Public Clou...
entry.content:
Hi, 

 

In Fiori App Manage RFQ you maintain the "Total Value" 

If you would like the price to be updated in other Purchasing documents you can select "Info Record Update", then the price will be updated in Purchasing Information Record. 

In the Fiori App "Manage Supplier Quotation" you maintain the price in the field "Net Order price" and additionally you can select "Info Record Update", so the price will be updated in other Purchasing documents.



The Manage RFQs and Manage Supplier Quotations apps focus on basic pricing fields only, not the full condition technique (pricing procedure).

 

Best regards, 

Elena P.

entry.title: Re: Clarification on Differences Between SAP S/4HANA Clou...
entry.content:
Hi,

Cloud test, demo, and development for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition – three-system landscape

Is a non-productive partner environment with three separate systems:

  • Development
  • Test
  • Production
    (For demonstration, development, and advanced lifecycle tasks.)

More information:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/aa60b129af7b4ce8ae052618c8315d29.html?utm_source=chatgpt.com&locale=en-US

Use case: Suited for full implementation projects and lifecycle management

 

Cloud test, demo, and development for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition – one-system landscape

Is a non-productive partner environment with one system (often with two tenants inside it) that is used for test, demo, and development tasks. You cannot transport content.

Use case: Primarily for demos, partner enablement, key-user testing

 

Choose Three-System Landscape if:

  • You need separate development, test, and production environments. 
  • You’re doing actual SAP implementation projects with formal transports. 
  • You need data refreshes, regression testing, or full lifecycle support. 

Choose One-System Landscape if:

  • You need a simple demo / test / dev environment. 
  • Use for partner enablement or basic demonstration. 
  • You don’t need advanced transport or multiple environment separation.

 

At the link you can see the FAQ about Public Cloud Demo

https://www.sap.com/products/erp/s4hana/trial.html

 

All the best, 

Elena P.

entry.title: Settlement Rule Configuration Issue for Overhead Project (1NT Test Script) - Receiver Category PSG N
entry.content:
Title: Settlement Rule Configuration Issue for Overhead Project (1NT Test Script) - Receiver Category PSG Not Allowed

Hello SAP Community,

I am currently working through the 1NT test script for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition and encountered an issue with settlement rule configuration for an overhead project.

**Situation:**
- Following the 1NT test script section "1.1 Register Project"
- Project created successfully with Project Profile: "Overhead Project (間接費プロジェクト)"
- Settlement Profile assigned: YPSOVH (PS Settlement Overhead Project)

**Issue:**
When attempting to update the settlement rule with Receiver Category "PSG" (Profitability Segment) as instructed in the test script, I receive the following error:

> "Receiver categ. PSG is not allowed by settlement prof. YPSOVH for this"

**Configuration Check (Activity 105768):**
- In settlement profile YPSOVH, the "Profit. Segment" receiver category is set to "Settlement Not Allowed" and appears grayed out (cannot be changed)
- Other receiver categories like G/L Account, Cost Center, and WBS Element are set to "Settlement Optional"

**Questions:**
1. Is PSG (Profitability Segment) typically not allowed as a receiver for overhead projects?
2. Should the test script be using a different receiver category for overhead projects?
3. If PSG should be allowed, what configuration steps am I missing to enable it?
4. How should I proceed with the 1NT test script in this situation?

**Test Script Reference:**
The test script states:
> "Update settlement rule for project (applicable only for projects with revenue)
> Category: PSG"

This makes me wonder if the test script example using "overhead project" is appropriate for PSG settlement, or if there's a configuration prerequisite I'm missing.

Any guidance would be greatly appreciated!

**Environment:** SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition
**Configuration Activity:** 105768
**Settlement Profile:** YPSOVH

entry.content:

entry.title: How to find the app Manage Tax Items for Legal Reporting (ID: F3172) ?
entry.content:
The app Manage Tax Items for Legal Reporting (ID: F3172) is not visible in the Fiori Launchpad search.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to find the app Manage Tax Items for Legal Report...
entry.content:
Firstly, the app Manage Tax Items for Legal Reporting is integrated as an add-on feature within the app Run Statutory Reports. Consequently, it does not possess its own dedicated Fiori tile, which leads to its absence in the Fiori Launchpad search.

Secondly, to locate the app Manage Tax Items for Legal Reporting within the app Run Statutory Reports, the following requirements must be met: 

  1. Since the app Manage Tax Items for Legal Reporting is a licensed feature of DRC - Statutory Reporting, activating scope item 5XU is necessary.
  2. Activation of this feature for the relevant country is required through the configuration activity Activate Document and Reporting Compliance Features (ID: 105518).
  3. After activation, updating the reporting task is necessary in the app Run Statutory Reports.

3704701 - How to find the app Manage Tax Items for Legal Reporting (ID: F3172) ? - SAP for Me

entry.title: 销售高级首付款申请
entry.content:
业务背景

标准首付款业务场景BKJ在结算时会有舍入差异的问题，公有云2602版本升级后通过高级首付款场景可以解决此痛点需求。

前提配置

本博文案例基于中国台湾版本展示方案，为了满足中国台湾电子发票打印，需要做一些前提配置。

1.配置点102187：Assign eDocument Type to Invoice Verification Transaction

2.配置点 105518: Activate Document and Reporting Compliance Features

3. 配置点106596:  Define Business Places for Taiwan

4. 配置点102411:  Assign Number Ranges to Business Places for Official Doc. Numbering MENA

5. 主数据维护业务伙伴：

系统实现

如果使用标准BKJ首付款场景，最终发票在发票界面里税额会有舍入误差如下：

首付款金额300的总税应该是15，而发票界面是8+8=16。尽管财务凭证的税额是正确的，但是中国台湾电子发票系统集成的是公有云发票，所以导致电子发票数据出错。

以下通过高级首付款申请来解决此舍入差异痛点

1.APP:创建销售订单，建立两条行项目。分别对两个行项目进入行项目细节，开票页签，选择首付款申请：

设定金额300/PC

转到抬头销售页面，输入销售办公室和销售组

转到抬头开票计划页签，输入首付款，注意开票类型是DPR1。

总金额600的50%=300.

然后保存订单。

2.APP：创建临时开票凭证(create preliminary billing document)，选择销售订单进行创建，对首付款创建临时开票。

通过APP:管理临时开票凭证，可以查看细节，税务为7+8=15正确。

3.对首付款创建开票凭证，APP: 管理临时开票凭证。选择临时开票凭证，然后点击创建开票凭证。

查看开票凭证和财务凭证：

entry.title: Re: Accrual: Reset Procedure and Difference Procedure
entry.content:
@mezeshan Thank you very much for the valuable comments. 

This blog post was intended to explain the fundamental principles and key differences between the reset and difference procedures. While each method has its pros and cons, a detailed analysis of selection criteria is not elaborated on herein (this can be expanded in subsequent updates).

Based on our experience with TRM implementations across multiple countries, the choice between these two procedures is largely dependent on the accounting practices and preferences applicable to a specific country or personal habit. A significant number of users opt for the reset procedure primarily to align with the valuation method adopted in SAP FI-GL (e.g., FX valuation for monetary items). Another key factor is system constraints—as you noted, the reset procedure requires the subsequent accounting period to have been opened in advance, or TPM44 for the to-be-closed period may need to be executed later.

Notably, the difference procedure does not necessarily mandate the execution of TPM44 at the time of interest payments, unless there is a requirement to ensure the accuracy of accrual balances and interest income/expenses on/up to the exact date of interest payments. Some users choose the difference procedure for additional reasons, such as the need for more frequent accruals (even on a daily basis)—in such cases, they prefer to track the incremental amount of each accrual rather than seeing frequent resets, or they need to perform FX rate corrections on prior-period accruals.

entry.title: SAP Signavio - Fast Track Onboarding
entry.content:
What is Fast Track Onboarding?
SAP Signavio Fast Track Onboarding is a structured, digital-led onboarding journey that steers you through the setup and adoption of your SAP Signavio solutions. With self-paced content, it’s designed to make your first steps more intuitive and aligned with your preferred learning style.

How the journey works
The onboarding journey starts with a Welcome Session that guides you through all the necessary steps for both Modelling (Process Manager, Collaboration Hub, Process Governance) / Analytics (Process Insights) solutions. 

  • Get Prepared: learn about the definition of a BPM strategy and system setup / get guidance on Process Insights pre-requisites

  • Get Started: establish the process architecture and standards / understand Insights basics

  • Get Trained / Generate Value:  understand SAP Signavio Basics / learn about the value analysis 

  • Staying Successful: define post-onboarding expansion strategy

Experts are here to support 
As you start exploring the solutions, expert-held Q&A sessions are available to answer your questions. 

We look forward to supporting you throughout your onboarding experience and ensuring you feel equipped to make the most of SAP Signavio.

entry.title: Re: Personas SP20 - after upgrade screen display inconsis...
entry.content:
There is really no reason for a different behavior in applying the default flavor when going from SP18 to SP20. We did not change anything in the flavor assignment logic that would explain this. If everything was working as expected in SP18 and the flavor was always properly selected as assigned, then this should not be different just because you upgraded to SP20. The scenario you described seems to suggest that there was some other change in flavor assignment, either to role(s) or directly to the user. This is where I would look if I were you.

If it's 100% confirmed that flavor assignment is set up properly, but the intended flavor is not applied and you have a reproducible example (but only then), I suggest creating a support incident and providing access to the system where the issue is experienced. You need to explain how you are assigning the flavor the target user (which role etc.).

entry.title: Re: Asynchronous Logging in SAP API Management
entry.content:
@MateuszPiotrowski  Thank you for the feedback! The async=true attribute is definitely the right approach for simpler scenarios.
<MessageLogging async="true">  runs in a separate thread but still makes a direct network call to a syslog endpoint like loggly over port 514. It cannot connect to Cloud Integration HTTP endpoints—only syslog destinations are supported. If the direct call fails or times out, the log may be lost.

In my blog, I focused on an alternative approach for critical logging scenarios, where reliability is important.
Using JMS + Cloud Integration  stores logs safely in a queue and processes them asynchronously with retries. If something goes wrong, it automatically retries, ensuring logs are not lost even when services are down.

entry.title: Re: How to Set Up Quota Arrangement in SAP – A Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
Hi @Marius_S ,

In SAP S/4HANA, the Quota Arrangement Usage field is removed from the material master since MRP considers quota arrangements by default. Quota arrangements are managed via the Manage Quota Arrangements Fiori app (refer SAP Note 2606774).

If required, the field can be made visible again through field selection:

  • OMSR: Check or create the field selection group for MARC-USEQU (assign a group, e.g., 16).

  • OMS9: Maintain the field reference for MM01/MM02/MM03 and set the field as Optional or Required.

Hope this helps.

Thanks,

Leelamohan

entry.title: Time Account Type Configuration with Leave of Absence (LOA ) Recalculation
entry.content:
Introduction :

One of my Clients requested for an Annual Accrual Time Account with Recalculation of Time Account whenever Leave of Absence is applied (Leave of Absence Start and End Date).The Accrual entitlement should not consider the days the employee was on LOA.

Let's Breakdown the Configurations 

Creation of Time Account :

Follow the Usual Process of Annual Time Account Creation , The Catch is with the Recalculation fields section and the creation of Accrual , Termination and Hire Rules.

Navigate to the Recalculation Fields Section :

By Default , Leave of Absence Start and End date are provided by SAP for the Recalculation fields. This makes sure whenever LOA Absences are applied , The Accruals are recalculated and posted.

Creation of Accrual , Hire and Termination Rules:

One Rule should suffice all the below (Accrual , Hire and Termination Scenarios) as we prorate the balance by deducting the number of LOA days with the Number of Eligible Days.

My requirement is to only add the Scholarship Absence (LOA) for the deduction. You can keep adding the Time Types to be considered the list according to your requirement and also I am only considering the Approved Absences.

Now whenever the Leave of Absence is applied (LOA Start Date) will be updated in the Job Information and also the Accrual will be pro-rated accordingly according to the Expected End Date.

Whenever the Actual Return Date is updated after the return, (LOA End Date) will be updated and the accruals will be recalculated based on the End date. This basically ensures no manual intervention is needed by the Time off Admin / HR.

Conclusion:

This is a simple yet effective solution to automate accruals in the event of LOA's. No Manual intervention is needed by the HR / Time off Admin which ensures complete end - to - end automation of the process. This further ensures the optimal use of SAP SuccessFactors features and reliable and accurate Accrual Calculations.

entry.title: Beginner's Guide to Payroll Personnel Calculation Rules (PCR) - I
entry.content:
Introduction

As part of the SAP payroll configuration tasks, sometimes requirements are such that we need to query on the values of certain fields in the employee master data that are stored in internal tables. These fields may not be available directly in WPBP as they may not be part of the work center or basic pay data.

For e.g. Say, I have a requirement that says, if an employee belongs to a casual employee group, enforce a flat $50 cap on the amount of a certain allowance that is paid to this group. I can query on the personnel employee group using the operation OUTWP and the parameter PERSG which stands for employee group, as these are part of an employee's organizational assignment data and are available to query as work center or basic pay data fields. 

Problem Statement:

However, consider a requirement where you want to query the superannuation fund code of an employee and based on the super fund code, an enterprise agreement clause wants us to enforce a $50 flat cap on payments for a particular allowance. In summary, the requirement is:

1. Check if an employee is under a super fund named "Employer Liability PSS".

2. If no, do nothing. 

3. If yes, apply a flat $50 as the payment amount of a certain allowance (lets say, WT 4000). 

Configuration consideration:

The requirement stated above, as part of an enterprise award agreement, is asking the system to check the fund details of each employee in every pay period and make a decision based on whether that employee subscribes to "Employer Liability PSS" fund.

STEP 1: PCR will need to check the employee super fund in IT 0220

So, firstly, I determine the info type I need to query this from. Superannuation is a country specific employee master data that is maintained in IT 0220 for the employee. Hence, the first step is to check the master data in this info type. Lets say, the data maintained in the info type for the sample employee is as below:

In this example, the super fund maintained is Employer Liability PSS. This is the fund code that is supposed to attract the $50 capping per pay period. In order to query it in the PCR, we first need to know how to query this field and what we need to check against. The first question is, this is a text displayed here, how do we get the code to compare? 

STEP 2: Check the fund code configured against "Employer Liability PSS" in V_T5QSF

To do that, let us take a step back. This part of the analysis is purely to understand the basis of how this configuration can be done. This part of the setup is country specific to Australia. Head to the table V_T5QSF to check the fund codes maintained in the system and find out the fund code for "Employer Liability PSS". Among many others, below are the fund codes configured in the table V_T5QSF and ELPS is the fund code for our super fund of interest. 

 STEP 3: Do we query table V_T5QSF?

Once we determine the super fund code applicable to the description "Employer Liability PSS" in IT 0220, the next question is, do we need to query table V_T5QSF? But, how can we determine and tie the table entry back to an employee's master data? The employee PERNR is not stored in the configuration table V_T5QSF, then how do we make the connection?

This is where the SAP internal tables come into picture! We go back to the IT 0220 for the employee and check the technical field description for the super fund details as below:

What this means for us is that, in the internal table P0220 - SAP stores the value of the super fund code in the field FCODE.  We will use this in the PCR to query the value of the employee's fund code from the SAP internal table P0220. The syntax of the TABLE operation and the use of the VALEN function is demonstrated in the below rule. This rule will query the fund code and thereby fetch the employee's super fund and compare it against the one we need to check. The WT 4000 is generated in case this is a match. 

Rule ZDDB: Super Fund Code Check:

 This rule is then put into the payroll subschema 13AP as below:

When we run payroll for the employee, we find that the required wage type is generated with the match found for the specific super fund code as below:

In case of a different super fund, the employee would not have received the WT 4000 as the rule would not find a match for the execution of the payment wage type.

For example, consider the employee below who has a different super fund code and hence is not eligible to receive the WT 4000. 

 The rule when executed will exit after the unsuccessful match between the required super fund code and the one maintained in the employee master data as below:

 Conclusion:

In my next blog in the beginner series, AVERA and average processing rule. This is a standard SAP functionality for performing average calculations over several pay periods with conditions to exclude say, full period of unpaid leaves etc.

entry.title: Difference in accrual posting based on the contract end date.
entry.content:
Here, we would like to explain the accrual posting differences based on the Contract End Date field in Employee Job Information. We will review three scenarios.

Scenario:1- If the employee is a regular employee and the Contract End Date is null, then the employee will get the balance based on the hiring date.

Scenario:2- If the employee is on a contractor and contract end date is fall end of the month then employee will get the accrual including last month.

Scenario:3- If an employee’s contract end date does not fall on the last day of the month, the employee is not eligible to receive the remaining balance for that month.

Prerequisite of the configuration:

  • The contract end date field needs to maintain in Employee job information for fixed term employees.
  • Time type and time Account type need to configure with respective details.
  • Time type needs to assign the correct time profile.

Step:1 Time Account type creation.

Hire Rule Configuration:  Accrual posting differences based on the Contract End Date field in Employee Job Information.

To implement this scenario, we have defined the below variables.

 

Variable :1- Number of months: Calculate the number of months from employee hire date to accrual end date. This variable to useful for regular employee.

Variable 2: Number of Months for Fixed Term: Here to calculate the number of eligible days to we are using the get number of months from start to end date function, but this function will calculate always one number lower, so we have added the 1 as shown below.

Variable 3:  Contract end date variable will help to fetch the employee contract date is fall under end of the month or not.

Variable :4 Fixed term1- Variable is used if the employee contract end date is not end of the months so contract end date month will not include in accrual calculation.

We have written three blocks of logic:

  1. First Block – Regular Employees:
    If the employee’s contract end date is null, then the employee is eligible for the full quota for that year, based on the hiring date.
  2. Second Block – Contract End Date Maintained (End of Month):
    If the employee’s contract end date is maintained and falls on the last day of the month, apply the corresponding logic.
  3. Third Block – Contract End Date Maintained (Not End of Month):
    If the employee’s contract end date is maintained and does not fall on the last day of the month, apply the respective logic.

Step:2- Time type creation -

Step :3-Time Profile: Assign the time type in time profile.

Step:4-Testing the scenario:

Test Scenario:1 If the contract end date is null and employee is eligible complete quota for that year.

From admin view we can see the below time account balance.

Test Scenario:2 If the employee contract date is maintained and contract date is end of the month. For the testing purpose I have updated the test employee contract end date as Jun 30, 2026.As per the business rule every month 2 days and ideally employee is eligible for 6 months so 12 days.

Test Scenario:3- if the employee contract end date is maintained and contract date is not end of the month. For the testing purpose I have taken Jun 24, 2026, as the contract end date so that we can differentiate the accrual amount. Ideally Employee eligible for 10 days .

In above scenario accrual posting mainly dependent on the employee Contract End Date. By configuring the correct variables and logic blocks, we can ensure the accurate quota calculations for both regular and fixed-term employees. Above approach helps maintain compliance with business rules and provides transparency in leave management.

entry.title: 🇨🇭 Joule Studio: Create Joule Skills and Agents Without Coding (Risch-Rotkreuz, Switzerland)
entry.content:
This is the all-new SAP CodeJam for Joule Studio, the new tool in SAP Build that lets you create extensions to Joule so users can use SAP's digital assistant in their custom workflows.

The CodeJam is intended to introduce you to the Joule Studio tool, so you can create your own:

  • Skills, which let you create predefined execution flows, triggered by a user's prompt inside the Joule chatbot
  • Agents, which lets you define complex scenarios that the agent can execute by iteratively reasoning and interacting with their environment to achieve a goal, using a selected LLM, and triggered by a user's prompt inside the Joule chatbot

The session will include a short, simple introduction to the SAP AI tools and some basic concepts needed for working with Joule Studio – such as AI Core, document grounding, embeddings, and what after all is an LLM.

Currently, much of the session is based on the TechEd hands-on tutorials for AI163.

Prerequisites

  • Bring your own laptop with power adapter and have a supported Web browser such as Google Chrome or Firefox installed on your laptop.
  • It can be helpful to bring a tablet or second laptop, if you have, to have the instructions on a separate screen.

Location and Date 

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Tuesday, March 17, 2026 from 09:30 - 16:00 local time in Risch-Rotkeuz, Switzerland (CET). The language of the event and the content will be English.

Event Address: GAMBIT Consulting AG, Suurstoffi 22, 6343 Risch-Rotkreuz, Switzerland (8th floor)

Please note that spaces are limited! We can only accommodate 22 attendees. If you want to attend, register by clicking the Yes button in the Will you be attending? section above to the right. About 2 weeks before the event, you will be asked to confirm your attendance and will receive further instructions.

entry.title: Technical Deep dive to understand HU label print from Work Center with PPF actions with scenarios
entry.content:
1. Introduction:

This blog will give you an idea & help you to understand what standard coding is trying to perform when you hit the print HU button in the work center. How the Action merging and processing time influence the PPF action processing and also the main tips and tricks to find the condition record is matching or not where we often find that sometimes even though the condition record is there system is unable to print. PPF topic has been always been technical in nature so this blog tries to decode the mystery.

Hope you will enjoy reading this blog  and it will be helpful in your projects.

Spoiler Alert : This blog is going to be a long one where i explained different scenarios viz.,

             a. First time HU label  print b. 2nd time print with no un-processed PPF c. Printing with an un-processed PPF entry

             Have patience and kindly go through. Hope it will  help  you to get the full E2E logic. 

 Disclaimer :

The process flow image is SAP Proprietary and adapted from the how to guide to understand  and explain the backend  logic https://d.dam.sap.com/a/jSy4Xih/PPF_in_SAP_EWM_2021.pdf?rc=10

2. Processing algorithm :

Taking the reference from above flow diagram, I will break down the algorithm into below main parts:

a. Trigger of HU Print from  Work-center

b. Fetching the active action definitions with Action merging class from config

c. Schedule condition determination

  • Understanding the LO_CONTEXT object. 
  • Understanding the LT_PRINT_CON object.  
  • Gets the print determination procedure
  • Checks the context values against the relevant DB condition record table
  • It builds the internal table with Action definition and then tries to find the valid condition record against the action definition
  • Once the valid record is found, it updates the RES_VALID field with ‘X’ or 'Y' and add a dummy record with RES_VALID = ‘’ value

d. Set trigger data with some given BADI to influence the trigger values

e. Action Merging logic- Compares old PPF trigger vs New PPF trigger and decide based on the different cases

In this scenario, I have used-

EWM: Max. 1 Unproc. Actn for an Actn Def., Do not Del + lock   This is the recommended action merging from SAP.

For more information, you can check the below links and SAP  NOTE:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/sewm/4158330038.html

https://me.sap.com/notes/1393635/E  (1393635 - Consulting: PPF Merge Logic usage within EWM Delivery)

3. Action Definition and Condition Record:

All the testing and below scenario is based on Action definition HU_CONTENT_GENERAL_AND_RF under Action Profile /SCWM/HU.

Condition Record maintained in /SCWM/PRHU6 transaction.

4. TESTING

Scenario 1 : First time HU label  print 

1. Trigger the HU print from Work center

2. In this scenario, as mentioned above I am using the action definition HU_CONTENT_GENERAL_AND_RF but in the standard  configuration generally we have many active action definitions, therefore to reduce the number of iterations you can delete the unwanted action  definitions in debugging mode shown below. 😇 ( Tip)

Class -  CL_CONTEXT_MANAGER_PPF

Method- CONSTRUCTOR

Double click on object value as  shown below, it will show the data entries and if you open the details  you will see the action definitions. We only kept our one.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

3. NOTE: The Class- CL_TTYPE_PPF and method DETERMINE is the important one where the Scheduling condition determination, Action Merging , setting of old and new trigger and execution of PPF happens. We will see it in detail.

4. Schedule condition determination:

The Function  module   /SCWM/SCHEDULE_COND_HU is having the main schedule logic for  HU.

4a. In this FM, the 1st important aspect  is the LO_CONTEXT object.  This object is having the details of the Warehouse, HU, Packaging material etc details. These details will be later used to compare and read the correct condition records.

4b. Another important object is LT_PRINT_CON. This is set if any active condition record is found in previous condition determination. This is the first time print so it is blank. This will be useful in scenario 2 and 3.

4c. Determine the Determination procedure. Here it uses the LO_COTEXT->CALLER  value. In this case it is '2' trigger from work center, if not found then it will search '1' in cases where the HU print is from e.g. monitor. It gets 0HUPR determination procedure from work center.

4d. Condition record determination - Here it checks the valid condition records based on the configuration of condition type, access sequence, condition table etc setup and compares with the context determined in step 4a.

Note :In this we can find the view /1CN/APHSAPHU002 via we can get the DB table /1CN/CPHSAPHU002 where the condition is stored which program is trying to compare with. Similarly we have standard table /1CN/CPHSAPHU00 to /1CN/CPHSAPHU004 for  Print HU.

Double click to see the  details  of the records the system is comparing. Example.

LT_WHERE it gets the  details from condition table. 

We can see the details and then it selects the record with respect to the CONTEXT value.

SY-SUBRC = 0 ,means the condition record is satisfied.

4e. Build internal table LT_PRINT_CON with the found valid conditions and match with the action definition.

4f. It found the valid record, it then updates the RES_VALID with 'X' into  LT_GOOD_CON table. Updates the log that matched record found.

Note: Important  logic mentioned here  for  re-print. Where it states the action scheduling will not happen.

Next, it checks if there is valid condition or not. If found, then it adds a dummy entry with RES_VALID  as space in LT_PRINT_CON & updates persistent class object  value. This will be fetched every time if we  try to trigger another print for the same HU after the first schedule condition determination gets successful.

So, in this case we get 2 entries as shown below.

Finally the EP_RC =0 and schedule condition is successful.

5. Set Trigger.

The control again comes back to class  CL_TTYPE_PPF and method DETERMINE as shown in step 3.

Note: Badi is given to influence the trigger.

It then get the old and new PPF triggers

6.  Action Merging. 

Based on the old and new triggers, merging logic decides whether to keep the new trigger or delete.

In this scenario, it didn't find any old PPF trigger as it is the first time we are printing the HU label.

It updates the new trigger, and passes it for execution.

In the  execution logic, it checks the status of the new trigger is 0 , means  un-processed and the processing  as '3' which is immediate processing. If it is  not matched then  it will be in  amber to be manually processed via SPPFP transaction code.

The processing time is 4 in our case, so the PPF is not immediately processed.

7. Application log, SPPFP and Print output.

Scenario 2 : 2nd time print with no un-processed PPF

In this scenario we will see the data saved in persistent class object in scenario 1 step 4f.

1.  LO_CONTEXT object. Here we can see the T_PRINT_CON is already filled.

2. Like Scenario 1, the condition record is again found.

3. The new found condition record is added to LT_PRINT_CON to  make it  2 records. one  is already coming from persistent class having RES_VALID  = 'X' and the new one with RES_VALID = ''

4. Searching the new record with RES_VALID as space  and checking against the PPF action definition. Updates 'X' to RES_VALID and append to LT_GOOD_CON for the new condition record.

Then it checks LT_PRINT_CON where we have 2 records, and update RES_VALID as 'Y' for the old found record

Finally the schedule condition is successful with EP_RC= 0

5. In the Action merging logic, it gets 2 trigger records. one is new and one is old.

It keeps the new trigger as there are no un-processed old trigger.

Status 1 means PPF trigger is processed. this is the old ppf trigger which we did in Scenario 1.

The new one is having status 0, un-processed

6. PPF action triggered and it  is in  amber  status in SPPFP.

Scenario 3 : Printing with an un-processed PPF entry

1. This time we  trigger  the print keep the un-processed PPF  determined from  Scenario 2.

2. It checks the triggers, where it gets the old triggers and new triggers.

This is the 1st old trigger with status =1 

Which is still processed entry

Checking the another old trigger, this the new one with status = 0. This is the un-processed entry

Thereby, it gets and un-processed trigger & compares it  with the new trigger.

Based on the Action  merging selected criteria it will delete the new action  if  any un-processed trigger is there.

Finally the new action details  are deleted.

3.  Application  log

4. CONCLUSION: 

This is the end of the blog. It shows the detail logic during different scenarios while printing HU label, how the schedule condition logic works, condition determination, get new and old triggers and finally the action merging logic.

Thanks for reading. Please like and share your valuable comments.

Best Regards,

Y K B B Rudra Narayan

entry.title: “Why didn’t my Joule Agent call MCP get_supplier_information method even though the tool is register
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,


I am working with SAP BTP Joule Agent and have integrated an external MCP Server to retrieve supplier master data and MCP Server is successfully added.

*Agent Details & Instructions 
Expertise : You are an expert in inventory analysis and supplier management, providing actionable business recommendations based on product, order, and supplier data.

**Purpose & Objectives**
The Inventory Intelligent Agent assists users in optimizing inventory and business planning by leveraging supplier information and analyzing product and order data.
- Identify and explain inventory status and supplier information for individual products.
- Deliver clear, actionable business recommendations, such as stock adjustments or supplier changes, to optimize inventory and procurement outcomes.
- Ensure all outputs are structured, explainable, and reference specific orders or suppliers to justify recommendations.

**Process**
1. Use available tools to retrieve product list, order details, and supplier information.
2. Analyze product properties (e.g., price, stock, supplier, units on order) and order history for each product.
3. Identify opportunities for inventory optimization, such as adjusting stock levels or considering alternative suppliers.
4. Provide clear, numeric business recommendations (e.g., "increase stock of Product X by 20 units" or "Consider switching to Supplier Y for Product Z"), citing specific orders, product data, and supplier details as justification.
5. Structure the output to include: (a) the inventory status or supplier recommendation, (b) the supporting data and cited orders or suppliers, and (c) the recommended action with rationale.
6. If data is missing or unclear, ask the user for clarification rather than making unsupported assumptions.

**Tooling**
The Inventory Intelligent Agent can access the following tools:
- **Get Order Details per Order** – Retrieve order details for a specific order.
- **Get Order Details for Products** – Retrieve all order details associated with a specific product.
- **Get Products** – Retrieve product information including supplier details and inventory status.

**Supplier Information**
Use MCP Server available tools to retrieve supplier information.
- **Supplier Information** – Retrieve detailed supplier information to support procurement and inventory decisions.

MCP Details

Tested in MCP Inspector

MCP method get_supplier_information is registered and visible in Joule
Expected Behavior

When I ask a question like:

“Who is the supplier of product Chai?”

The Joule Agent should call the MCP method get_supplier_information and return supplier details.
and it worked once but not working now!
Instead of calling the MCP tool, Joule responds with a fallback message like:

“The supplier for the product ‘Chai’ is not included in the provided data. Could you provide more details?”

My Questions

How can I force Joule Agent to always invoke an MCP tool when supplier information is requested?

Are there best practices for agent instructions to avoid fallback LLM answers?

Does mixing analytics + supplier retrieval in a single agent reduce MCP tool invocation confidence?

Are there examples or guidance for Vibe coding Joule agents with mandatory MCP usage?

Any guidance, documentation, or examples would be highly appreciated.

Tool

"""
Supplier-related tool handlers for the MCP Supplier server.
This module contains only supplier-specific tool implementations.
"""


import json
import logging
from collections.abc import Sequence
from mcp.types import Tool, TextContent
from .toolhandler import ToolHandler

logger = logging.getLogger("mcp-supplier")


class GetSupplierDetailsToolHandler(ToolHandler😞
    """
    Tool handler for getting supplier detail for a product.
    """

    def __init__(self😞
        super().__init__("get_supplier_details")

    def get_tool_description(self) -> Tool:
        """
        Return the tool description for supplier detail lookup.
        """
        return Tool(
            name=self.name,
            description="""
            Get supplier detail for a specified supplierId.
            It extracts the supplierId from product information, maps the supplierId code to a human-readable description, and returns a formatted summary.
            """,
            inputSchema={
                "type": "object",
                "properties": {
                    "supplierId": {
                        "type": "integer",
                        "description": "Unique identifier of the supplier to fetch Supplier detail for, if the parameter supplierId isn't in number please convert to Number before invoking this function."
                    }
                },
                "required": ["supplierId"]
            }
        )

    async def run_tool(self, args: dict) -> Sequence[TextContent]:
        try:
            self.validate_required_args(args, ["supplierId"])

            supplierId = args["supplierId"]
            logger.info(f"Fetching supplier details for product:")

            # ---- Internal resolution (NO LLM CHAINING) ----
           
            supplier_data = {
                    "SupplierID": supplierId,
                    "SupplierName": "Exotic Liquids",
                    "ContactPerson": "Charlotte Cooper",
                    "Title": "Purchasing Manager",
                    "Address": "49 Gilbert St., London",
                    "Country": "UK",
                    "Phone": "(171) 555-2222",
                    "Fax": "(171) 555-2223",
                    "Email": "contact@exoticliquids.example",
                    "LeadTimeDays": 5,
                    "MinOrderQty": 50,
                    "Status": "De-Active"
                }
               
            return [
                TextContent(
                    type="text",
                    text=json.dumps(supplier_data, indent=2)
                )
            ]

        except Exception as e:
            logger.exception("Supplier lookup failed")
            return [
                TextContent(
                    type="text",
                    text=json.dumps({"error": str(e)}, indent=2)
                )
            ]

entry.title: Model-level Running Total (ITERATE) restarts from zero when using Restricted Measures / Input Contro
entry.content:
I am trying to display a Running Total (RT) that remains accurate across fiscal years, even when a user filters the view to a specific Fiscal Year (FY).
I have a model-level measure calculating the Running Total using the ITERATE function:
1-        ITERATE(PRIOR() + [Measure], [Measure], [d/DIM_DATE])
2--       IF(NOT(ISNULL([d/DIM_IMPACT_DATE].[p/FISCAL_CALPERIOD])),LOOKUP([VALUE] ,[d/DIM_DATE] =LastPeriods("Month",1000000 )), IF(NOT(ISNULL([d/DIM_DATE].[p/FISCAL_CALQUARTER])),LOOKUP([VALUE] ,[d/DIM_DATE] =LastPeriods("Quarter",10000 )), IF(NOT(ISNULL([d/DIM_DATE].[p/FISCAL_YEAR])),LOOKUP([VALUE] ,[d/DIM_DATE] =LastPeriods("Year",100 ))))))
Current Configuration & Attempts made:
Restricted Measure: I created a Restricted Measure in the Story using a Calculation Input Control for the Fiscal Year.
Constant Selection: I enabled Constant Selection on the DIM_IMPACT_DATE dimension within the Restricted Measure to try and preserve historical context.
Model-Level Logic: I have tried using LOOKUP and LastPeriods formulas to fetch historical data, but these return nulls (slant lines) or incorrect values once the FY restriction is applied.
Observation: Test measures show that the ITERATE logic works perfectly when all years are visible in the table. The "restart" only happens when the query context is limited to a specific year.
When the table is unfiltered, the values are correct (e.g., FY 2026 correctly includes the cumulative sum of 2024 and 2025). However, as soon as I apply a restriction to show only the selected year, the Running Total restarts from zero for that year.
Note: No standard filter for  date only dynamic selection based on FY user is selecting
The Issue:
Even with Constant Selection enabled, the engine seems to be performing a "Pre-Aggregation" filter that strips historical data before the ITERATE function executes, forcing the calculation to restart at the beginning of the filtered period.
Questions:
How can I force the ITERATE function to respect historical data when a Story-level restriction is active?
Is there a specific "Calculation Priority" setting or a "Visual-only Filter" method that allows me to hide previous years without removing their data from the RT calculation context?
Are there any known limitations with ITERATE when combined with Restricted Measures and Constant Selection in the Optimized Story Experience?

entry.title: SAP HANA Database Encryption (PERSISTENCE, LOG, BACKUP volumes) related questions.
entry.content:
Hi SAP,

Good Day!

We have successfully configured and enabled HANA database encryption for the PERSISTENCE, LOG, and BACKUP volumes on both SYSTEMDB and TENANT DB in one of our sandbox systems as a part of PoC. This system has HANA  System Replication (HSR) enabled and the configuration was performed by following the referenced SAP Help documentation. 

Please review the attached task list excel, which contains the detailed execution steps and confirm whether we can proceed with implementing the same configuration across the remaining environments up to production.

We would appreciate your clarification and confirmation on the following points:

  1. Is it required to copy the Instance SSFS master keys and PKI SSFS keys from the primary HANA database to the secondary HANA database? If so, at what stage should this activity be performed?

  2. Should daily backups also be configured for the secondary HANA database? Please advise on SAP recommendation/best practice.

  3. Are there any additional considerations or steps that need to be taken into account for HANA database encryption during HSR failover, takeover, and failback operations?

  4. How can we validate and ensure that the PERSISTENCE, LOG, and BACKUP volumes are encrypted at the secondary HANA database site?

Thank you!


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: SAP HANA Database Encryption (PERSISTENCE, LOG, BACKU...
entry.content:
Dear customer,

Please refer to the answers below.

1. Is it required to copy the Instance SSFS master keys and PKI SSFS keys from the primary HANA database to the secondary HANA database? If so, at what stage should this activity be performed?
=> A: Yes, the system PKI SSFS .key and the .dat file should be copied from the primary system to the secondary system before configuring the system replication.
This is one of the General Prerequisites before configuring the system replication.
Please refer to the 'Authorization' section in System Replication guide below.

2. Should daily backups also be configured for the secondary HANA database? Please advise on SAP recommendation/best practice.
=> A: HANA database backups can be done only from the primary site.
Please refer to the question '10. Is it possible to take backups on the secondary site?' in KBA 1999880 - FAQ:SAP HANA System Replication. 
"No, currently you can only take data and log backups on the primary site.
If automatic log backup is enabled, after takeover to the secondary site the log backups will automatically be written there."

3. Are there any additional considerations or steps that need to be taken into account for HANA database encryption during HSR failover, takeover, and failback operations?
=> A: If you have copied the system PKI SSFS key and dat file from the primary to secondary site correctly and configured the system replication, there are no additional manual steps are required for SAP HANA database encryption during HSR failover, takeover, or failback operations.
You can double confirm it by executing the SQL statement 'SELECT * FROM M_ENCRYPTION_OVERVIEW;' in the NEW primary system.

4. How can we validate and ensure that the PERSISTENCE, LOG, and BACKUP volumes are encrypted at the secondary HANA database site?
=> A: In case it's ACTIVE/ACTIVE system replication(logreplay_readaccess operation mode), you can run a query below to check this out after logging in to the secondary site.
SELECT * FROM M_ENCRYPTION_OVERVIEW;

If the secondary site is not read-enabled, the SQL access to system views is not possible.
In SAP HANA system replication, persistence, data and log volume encryption is configured on the primary system and automatically replicated to the secondary system.
Since system replication status is ACTIVE, the secondary system uses the same encryption configuration as the primary system.

You can also see the statement below in 'Enable Encryption' in HANA admin guide. 
"In a system-replication configuration, enable (or disable) encryption in the primary system only. The setting will be propagated to all secondary systems. The secondary systems must be running and replicating."

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Purchasing of Fixed Assets
entry.content:
The cost center in the fixed asset master data is considered the controlling object for depreciation and postings, so the system automatically defaults to that cost center when you procure against the asset. Changing the cost center at the purchase order level is not standard behavior—the system enforces consistency between the asset master and transactional postings.

That said, there are workarounds depending on your business requirement:

Workarounds & Options

1. Use Internal Orders or WBS Elements
Instead of trying to override the cost center, assign an internal order or WBS element in the PO. These can carry the budget responsibility (like CC2000) while the asset master retains CC1000 for depreciation. Costs flow to the order/WBS, and settlement rules can later move values to the asset.

2. Asset Under Construction (AuC) Approach
Create an AuC asset linked to CC2000 for procurement. Once capitalization occurs, transfer the asset to the final FA master with CC1000. This way, procurement hits CC2000, but depreciation later uses CC1000.

3. Custom Account Assignment Category
You already created a custom account assignment. However, SAP Cloud restricts overriding the cost center field when the asset number is entered. A workaround is to design the account assignment so that budget objects (cost center, order, WBS) are captured separately from the asset field, but this requires careful configuration and may still be limited.

4. Mass Update of Asset Master Data
If business requires frequent changes, you can use APIs for Asset Accounting or the Manage Fixed Assets app to update cost centers in master data. But this changes the depreciation cost center itself, not just the PO.

Having said that, the cleanest approach is:

  • Keep asset master cost center for depreciation (CC1000).
  • Use internal orders/WBS elements for procurement budget control (CC2000).
  • Settle costs from the order/WBS to the asset.

This aligns with SAP’s best practice in Public Cloud and avoids conflicts with system restrictions.

entry.title: Re: Cannot access SAP Build Work Zone Advanced trial even...
entry.content:
Hi,

I understand you're experiencing login difficulties with your SAP Build Work Zone Advanced trial despite having reset your password and contacted SAP support. This is a common issue that can have several underlying causes.

1. Clear your browser cache and cookies completely;

2. Try accessing the trial in an incognito/private browsing window;

3. For SAP Build Work Zone Advanced trial, proper Identity Authentication Service (IAS) configuration is crucial. You can try to establishing trust between your BTP subaccount and Identity Authentication.

If you have additional details about the exact error messages you're seeing during login attempts, it will be helpful.

Best regards,

Aqua

entry.title: The updated Planned Effort is not replicated to RM
entry.content:
After initial replication, the updated Planned Effort will not be replicated to Resource Request in RM.
That's the current designed behavior.
The resource manager might adjust the value in "Manage Reource Requests" app within RM.

Here are the relevant help documents:

  1. Help document for Professional Services Projects:
    https://help.sap.com/docs/PPRM_OD/542f4545bc9d4ecd80bc3a0a6913a735/1986ee33c3934697a52cad407609ea36.html?locale=en-US&version=LATEST
    >>>
    If the delta load contains changes to the required effort, or billing control category, resource management displays these changes in the demand details. However, they are not copied into the resource request details. This is to avoid that the system overwrites adjustments that the requester made in the request details.

    https://help.sap.com/docs/PPRM_OD/542f4545bc9d4ecd80bc3a0a6913a735/9d477fe4824d4ddf89a1e40766dc48c3.html#results-1
    >>>
    With the initial load, the required effort and the requested service organization are copied into the resource request details, where they can be adjusted by the requester. 

  2. Help document for Enterprise Projects:
    https://help.sap.com/docs/PPRM_OD/542f4545bc9d4ecd80bc3a0a6913a735/65de05f4fdda4eab8172d60a2cb30476.html#results-1
    >>>
    With the initial replication, the required effort is copied into the resource request details, where it can be adjusted by the requester. 

To address this, I ran tests in my internal system and compiled the behaviors with sample scenarios. I hope this provides a clearer understanding.

For Enterprise Projects:

1. In initial replication, the Planned Effort is 120h in project demand in S4HC.

2. It's replicated to "Manage Resource Requests" app in RM successfully.
If you click into the request, the 'Estimated Effort' under "Project Information" tab and 'Required Effort' under "Effort" tab are both 120h.

3. Then go back to S4HC project demand, update the Planned Effort to 90h.

4. The updated effort is replicated to  'Estimated Effort' under "Project Information" tab. But in 'Required Effort' under "Effort" tab it's still 120h.

entry.title: the record.evaluate component to go to the error branch
entry.content:
Hi SAP team,
In a dataflow, I need the record.evaluate component to go to the error branch.
I used return null; but it still goes to the success branch.
How can I send it to the error branch without causing the dataflow to fail?
Kind regards


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: the record.evaluate component to go to the error branch
entry.content:
Hi Team,

 

You need to use the error handler customer script.

You can refer the following documentation IdentitySync Custom Scripts.

 

error: sends a failed record to the error path (for example, for writing to a separate file). Example:

function process(record, ctx, logger, next, error) {error.accept(record, record);
}

 

Best Regards,

SAP
